Fields.DialogueText: Where are the Morganas, Capitaine?
Is that a trick question?
... Where are the Morganas, Capitaine?
Right, I almost forgot it was you I was speaking to. That's what we're on patrol to find out.
C'est vrai. But we haven't found them out.

Fields.MenuText: Patrols aren't exciting enough for you?
I'll try and find a kraken for you to shoot.
Nobody joins the navy for the excitement.

Fields.DialogueText: Considering the purpose of the Belles is to destroy the Morganas, no, they are not.
Très drôle. I suppose we may make a comedian of you yet.
No wonder morale is so chronically low.
Has Command perhaps considered sending us to a known Morgana nexus?
You don't think it's enough to defend the coasts? At least for the time being?
Watch the cheese and the mouse will attack the grain. We need blue-water patrols, and we need them now.
You know how it is. Waiting for word from Command is part of the job, even in a potential emergency.
Command by committee. Merde.
Sometimes, there really is no other word for it.
D'accord. You're telling me that I should find us a real emergency.
I most certainly am not.
C'est la guerre, Capitaine. We must not wait for an emergency to find us. We do not sanctify the land with our wandering.
*ALARM*
Wish granted. We're coming up on a Morgana now.
At last.
@BATTLE
Merde. That was the third time this week.
The third time of what?
I caught one of the sailors telling ghost stories.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean, "ghost stories?"
You mean about the Morganas?
That sounds harmless to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Outlandish tales of the Morganas' powers. Nothing you need concern yourself with.
Précisément. Or about the horrors the crew believe them capable of.
You underestimate the power of superstition.
It's like we discussed. People will come up with explanations for the inexplicable. It's part of being human.
Peut-être. But haunting one's dreams at night? Drinking the blood of sailors? That is not part of being a Morgana.
How would you know?
Because it is not part of being a Belle.
I take your point - and I'll talk to the crew about these rumors if you're that concerned.
Bien. See that you do. Monsters the Morganas may be, but there is a line between respecting the enemy and fearing her. It is Fear, not Death, that slays.
Isn't half the crew convinced that you patrol their quarters listening for cowardice?
Ce n'est pas la même chose. I am not their enemy. Nor, as you well know, do I have to go looking for cowards among your crew.
Maybe I should talk to the crew about you.
Perhaps, once we have dealt with this demon to our northwest.
@BATTLE
And I'm glad for that. But there's a certain amount of evidence for Morganas influencing nightmares - you'll have seen the reports.
Oui. But if the crew is terrified of this kind of attack before it even comes, then they'll be all the more vulnerable to it.
Good news, Verdun! Orders from Command.
Enfin. Where would they send us?
Sevastopol. Stalin's keen on defending his biggest warm-water port.
Oui? Is that all he's keen on?
That's what Kuznetsov told Command.
The People's Commissar of the Navy. I find that suspect at best.

Fields.MenuText: You're thinking the Soviets have an ulterior motive?
We're not really in a position to question it either way.
I thought you wanted to be reassigned.

Fields.DialogueText: Quoi? You think they don't?
Non, but you must consider what is being asked for.
To one of the maelstroms, if at all possible.
I respect the Russian commitment to victory at any cost. But surely you know that in their country, "the People's" really means Stalin's.
Orders are orders. Belles are sworn to protect the coasts and seas...

... And not to be hired muscle. It's been some time since there was talk of Morgana activity near Sevastopol. The Turks have the Sea of Marmara locked down. What Stalin wants is to bleed his rivals dry.
Victory at any cost, no?
Only for the Soviet Union. I do not believe in cutting off one's nose to spite one's face. I fight wherever men are staunch and free. Weakening other navies is not the way.
So what do you propose?
For now, we will meet today's enemy. We will discuss our obligations to Command after.
@BATTLE
Has Command relented?
If you're talking about them ordering us to Sevastopol, I'm afraid not.
Merde. We've read the reports. You and I have seen that the Morganas menace the Mediterranean, the English Channel, the Straits of Malacca. The Black Sea is of minor concern.

Fields.MenuText: Not to the people who live there.
You have an alternative?
I think the Russians would disagree.

Fields.DialogueText: Everyone is afraid, Capitaine. That is what soldiers are for.
One that may solve all our problems.
Stalin does not speak for the Russians.
So what do you suggest?
Command have assigned our task force to the Black Sea, but it is you who decides how we are deployed, non?
That's right. What are you getting at?
Reduce the size of our Black Sea patrols. Show the world that such a large concentration of force is not necessary. I and a handful of my sisters will be more than enough.
And if you're not?
Impossible. The Dardanelles and the Bosphorus are fortresses. Should something extraordinary happen, we will have all the warning we require. That will teach Stalin where he can order us.
"From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs," eh? You'd think these Communists would have read Marx.
Marx? A poacher through and through. The socialist Louis Blanc said it first. A Frenchman, incidemment.
Ever the scholar.
As long as we are in Sevastopol, I should brush up on my Russian. Shall we teach today's Morgana some choice French curses?
Be my guest.
It shall be ease that asks not earning.
@BATTLE
What's that you're reading?
Something light for the journey to the Sea of Marmara.
... I wouldn't exactly call Les Misérables "light."
A soldier must keep her mind as sharp as her body, if not sharper. All the wisdom of the world is waiting for you on those shelves.
Don't the French Belles..."know" this book already?
It is part of our heritage, c'est vrai. But quoting the thing is different from reading and understanding it.

Fields.MenuText: Do you like it?
I'm not sure I understand that.
Do the other French Belles feel this way?

Fields.DialogueText: The Waterloo chapter alone is worth a novel.
I'm sure you know what the human heart looks like. But do you know what your heart looks like? That is my best stab at explaining.
Ça dépend. That minx Surcouf would be more interested in selling forged first drafts.
It's certainly good to have a hobby.
Je suppose.
Speaking of hobbies...
Capitaine...
I was just curious about your other one.
Go on.
I had to answer some interesting questions from Command about your requisitions. They were a little perplexed about what a Belle needs with chiffon.
I do not pry at your personal expenditures. Please offer me the same courtesy.
Sorry. You're usually so serious. I just figured I'd ask.
Pardon?
... I've been meaning to try out that new nylon chiffon. It's better for test pieces than silk. Moins cher.
Making a new dress? What's the occasion?
Gunpowder burns on the old one.
You practice shooting in a dress?
Perhaps you should, too. One must prepare for anything. Come to think of it, I have one or two that I don't wear often...
Is that the alarm I hear? We'd better get to action stations...and far away from this conversation.
@BATTLE
I appreciate your enthusiasm, Verdun, but this wouldn't be appropriate for a captain.
You don't like it?
No, it's not that. I just have to hold myself to a certain standard. If I'm seen wearing a...
Then why do you allow me to wear them?
That's different. Belle dress codes are situational at best, and the occasional burst of operatic style actually seems to be good for crew morale.
Bof! You said that it is good to have a hobby. Sharing a hobby with people who respect you doesn't look delusional. It's an exercise in trust, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: I never thought I'd say this, but you're making me miss serious Verdun.
... Fine. Just for a moment, and then it's back to business.
All right, I'll bite... but that's really not my color.

Fields.DialogueText: I take play as seriously as I take work. My curiosity will not be sated until I see this on you.
Merveilleux. Now, stand still while I pin this...
Je suis d'accord. Let me find something in black. That goes with everything.
Hey! Watch the pins!
Juste un de plus... et... fini! You may turn around now.
Verdun, I—oh, good lord.
Does it not suit you? I think it does.
... I suppose, in a way? Where did you get this?
This is one of mine, Capitaine. I had several bolts of chiffon in from Paris just last week.
Verdun, your skill as a seamstress is incredible. This is the sort of thing I'd expect to see on a runway...
Vigilance, Capitaine! I'm sensing Morganas advancing from the south!
Get to the bridge. As soon as I change out of this, I'll-
Swiftness of the tigress, Capitaine! They'll be upon us in minutes. Aux armes!
"Try on this ball gown for me, Capitaine! What's the worst that could happen, Capitaine?" Dammit dammit dammit.
@BATTLE
Shorter version - you can pull it off without looking delusional.
Ball gown.
I know, I know. If I'm spotted wearing ball gown around the ship it would just look... frivolous.
And I really do need to see how the fabric hangs on a human form.
No. No, no, no, no DAMMIT.
Can we talk for a moment?
Oui, Capitaine. De quoi voulez-vous parler?
Concerning the way you... handled the last Morgana fight.
Was my performance unsatisfactory?
Perhaps I should be clearer - concerning the way we handled the last Morgana fight.
As in...
Verdun, I can't command my crew in a dress. It's unbecoming.
Ah, oui. I quite agree. Then please accept my apology for putting you in that position.
Accepted and appreciated. As fun as it was, partaking in one of your hobbies with you, there's a time and a place for... oh, what's the saying?
Letting one's hair down?
That's it! Thank you, Verdun.
It is an interesting phrase. One of the Americans taught it to me just the other day.
Oh? Which one?
Signalman Crane. I reprimanded her this morning for letting her hair down on patrol.

Fields.MenuText: Letting her hair down how?
I'm glad I can count on you to keep the crew on task.
I'll see if I can't talk to her.

Fields.DialogueText: Literally. She said she'd braided it too tight. I recommended she shave it.
Without discipline, there is no morale. Without morale, there is no victory.
No need, Capitaine. The extra two kilometers on next week's morning runs will speak for themselves.
So you see why I wanted to talk to you. If we don't act professionally, what reason do we give our men to?
C'est vrai. They, as we, must be unswayed by love, friendship, home joy or home sorrow.
Unswayed by... what, now?
Brush up on your Hardy. Morganas approaching firing range. We will recoup our reputation in blood.
Thank you.
And I'll find you a better dress in port.
I don't know if that's really necessary...
To battle!
@BATTLE
The Aegean was clearer than I expected.
Je n'aime pas ça. The spotter planes reported dark clouds gathering over the Sea of Marmara, and here they are.
Visibility is terrible here. How's the radio?
Morte. Totalement morte.
Damn it. Morgana interference. We're practically stuck with searchlights and flags.
Weren't the Turks supposed to escort us through the Dardanelles?
Yes, but... wait. What's that on our northwest?
... Capitaine! Get down!
All hands brace for impact!
@BATTLE
I think it's safe to say that Turkey's having a rough time. Did their men get aboard safely?
All those who escaped the wreck of the Mecidiye. C'est-à-dire... twelve.
That's all that remained of the escort force?
Thiepval Ridge all over again.

Fields.MenuText: I know it's bad when you speak in Great War battles.
Where?
Are they all right?

Fields.DialogueText: Pray that I never run out of them.
Somewhere that hasn't yet recovered.
Back in the trenches, the word the poilus used was "shellshocked." That, but ten times worse.
We'll see to their recovery at once.
Bien sûr. But what of our mission?
We move forward. There's a blockade for us to run.
Oui, mon Capitaine. Let us sweep the smooth fluid grave of our soldiers.
@BATTLE
They just keep coming. It's nothing but Morganas from here to the Bosphorus.  How is the crew holding up?
Plutôt bien, all things considered. No madness or suicide that I am aware of. Though I would not recommend giving that time to change.

Fields.MenuText: Always the ray of sunshine.
All ahead full, then.
The Morganas are that bad?

Fields.DialogueText: If only to keep the ugliness of war from festering in the dark.
We've breached one strait. What is one more?
Worse, especially in numbers.
What about the Turkish sailors we picked up?
Silence. They have been decidedly unhelpful.
I'd chalk that up to their brush with death.
Ce n'est pas une excuse. What did they think they were signing up for?
Well, it certainly wasn't ghost ships.
So how much longer must they take up space in the infirmary?
Excuse me?
If they cannot fight, they must share what they know of the enemy so that we may fight. Failing that, the battlefield is no place for them.
Even so, Verdun, they're our responsibility until we can repatriate them.
D'accord. Shovel them under and let me work.
Capitaine, the Morganas lurk just beyond the Golden Horn. Have you heard the spotters' reports?
They aren't good. Both of the bridges have been destroyed, and they've been shelling Istanbul round the clock.
And yet she fights. Truly a city worth the defending.
Even if she didn't, it would be our job to defend her.
Morally? Peut-être. Strategically? She is useful for as long as she can hold the Morganas in place for us.

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to think you could use a vacation.
Just keep your eyes on the Black Sea.
Morality isn't totally worthless, you know. We fight because it's the right thing to do.

Fields.DialogueText: If I take one, it shall be at the bottom of the sea.
Through the holes in the witches' hulls, ideally.
Hmph. A gun speaks louder than a conscience.
What's gotten into you lately? It seems like only yesterday you were sewing a new ballgown.
Perhaps I was. How quickly I forget myself.
You're not making sense.
War does not make sense, Capitaine. You dance in the trenches one moment and are torn apart by a stray shell in the next. It may be that doing one enables you to bear the thought of the other.
I just don't understand how you can switch between the two so... violently.
My fashion and my fighting are incompatible. You have witnessed this firsthand in your dress.
I don't think that's the same as...
There is a time and a place for laughter, Capitaine. But when the shooting starts, lust and senseless hatred make me glad.
"Lust?"
Sois sérieux, Capitaine. Powerful desire for victory. It is only a necessity.
I see. Aim it at the Morganas, at least.
Toujours, Capitaine. Will you?
@BATTLE
Merde! Here they come again. That's the Morganas' third sortie now.
You'd think they'd get impatient and just advance.
Non. I would not.
It's an... never mind.
Tire!
@BATTLE
The air is loud with death, Capitaine... just the way I like it.
Thankfully not ours.
Shall we take the fight to them, Capitaine?
Briefly. That last sortie of theirs cleared out the strait in front of the Golden Horn. At the flagship's signal, we're taking this opening.
Très bien. They cannot pass, but we shall.
Then we're regrouping in the Black Sea and resupplying at Sevastopol.
Hmph. Stalin himself should present each man with a flask of vodka for answering his selfish call under fire.

Fields.MenuText: Just nod and smile, Verdun. We're only here for as long as it takes to restore order in the Black Sea.
Would it make you feel better if I found you something nice in port?
I'll be sure to ask him.

Fields.DialogueText: You may ask me to nod, Capitaine. I decide when I will smile.
... Peut-être.
While you're at it, tell him that his country looks beautiful on fire.
Right, then. We're first into the breach.
Is that supposed to be a compliment?
That depends on who lights the flames and why.
Action stations, Verdun! They're waiting for us on the other side of the Bosphorus.
Oui. They have no graves as yet... but we shall remedy that.
@BATTLE
C'est suprêmement exaspérante. They run, and run, and run, but they refuse to die.

Fields.MenuText: The rivers won't save them. Sooner or later they'll run out of sea.
That's not our mission today. For now, we've made the Sea of Marmara safe again.
Perhaps that's for the best. I've heard stories about what happens when they wreck.

Fields.DialogueText: It is a matter of duty. We drove them into a corner, and we shall be the ones to burn them in it.
Bien sûr, oui, but for how long?
S'il vous plaît, Capitaine, do not indulge in these fantasies. I have had to beat enough of them out of the crew.
In any case, we've finally made it to the Black Sea. A bit behind schedule, but...
But nothing. No plan survives contact with the enemy. Stalin will understand.
He's going to have to. But from what I hear from Sevastopol, they're holding up just fine.
Bien sûr. I ought to have ample time to catch up on my embroidery.
You're that confident about the enemy presence? Or lack thereof?
If I were Stalin, I would be more concerned about relations with Germany.
We'll have to wait and see.
Si vous le dites. I'll make you a tea cozy.
Something isn't quite right.
I was afraid you might say that. Have I stitched your jacket too tightly?
No, it's not that. I just can't shake the feeling that there's something wrong.
A common sentiment in the trenches. We call it "being at war."

Fields.MenuText: You really are getting better at sarcasm.
You're not the least bit concerned that there might be something we're missing?
Maybe you're right. Now, about this jacket...

Fields.DialogueText: I did not intend that as a joke, but one must take such victories as one is offered.
Presque jamais. Worrying is for those who have not made a habit of vigilance.
I will take your measurements again when I have an evening free.
Well, how are you finding Sevastopol?
Predictably sedate. I feel like I have been rotated off the front where I belong.
Insofar as anyone belongs in the line of fire.
That is the job of a destroyer. It's right there in the name.
Even so...
It is what I am for. You humans at least have the luxury of refusal.
Would you, if you could?
Do not mistake my resolution for resignation. It is not that I don't know how to do anything else. Killing is simply what I am best at, and it would be a waste not to do so.
It certainly doesn't hurt to have someone around who knows how to sew.
It does not, at that. In the meantime, we are useful. But you will learn, and then you may leave me to my expertise.
Making spectacular winter wear?
... Oui, ça aussi. I will finish your other coat after I persuade another Morgana to return to the cold.
@BATTLE
Getting some air?
Granting myself a break. I have been training your men again.
And you're the one who needs a break? Should I request more beds for the infirmary?
Perhaps fewer. It might give them incentive not to make mistakes.

Fields.MenuText: It must be nice to be invulnerable.
Define "mistakes."
Not every crew has the privilege of learning from a Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: It must be nice not to survive a torpedo to the fore.
Your crew has proven adept at doing so.
All the more reason not to squander it.
La guerre c'est l'enfer, Capitaine. How are they to withstand the monstrous anger of the guns if I do not expose them to the first few circles of hell?
I knew I shouldn't have let you read Dante.
I stopped reading Dante after Inferno. Too much theology for my blood.
That certainly explains your training. I keep hearing shouting at odd hours. What have you been doing with them lately?
The first rule of my training is not to discuss it.
First? What's the second?
Not to discuss it. Would you care to know the rest?
I think I get the idea. Look, if this has anything to do with the cricket bats you requisitioned... .
Ne soyez pas ridicule. I use them to beat dust out of my rugs. Though, now that you mention it...
Forget I said anything.
Comme vous le souhaitez. Today's Morgana should be an excellent palate cleanser.
@BATTLE
Regardez là, Capitaine. Are you seeing what I am seeing?
Looks like a bunch of civilians on the beach.
I was hoping a second set of eyes would prove me wrong.
I didn't think people still went to the beach these days. Too many Morganas about.
It is their funeral.
Now that you mention it... doesn't it look like that's what they're dressed for?
All in black? And on such a hot day... some new human fad?
No, I... good God!
Look on the bright side. We did not have to venture far to find our enemy.
@BATTLE
What did the away team find? Were we able to rescue anyone?
Pas une âme. Whatever they were planning, it went off without a hitch.

Fields.MenuText: If they were planning anything at all...
If only we'd seen them a little sooner.
Have you ever seen anything like it?

Fields.DialogueText: We did everything that could reasonably be expected. Perhaps unreasonably.
If only my hull were self-cleaning. It does not do to dwell on hypotheticals.
There are a few in every war.
It is almost like men standing up in the trenches during a bombardment.
That's suicide.
Pray that it is not contagious.
Something on your mind?
Comment avez-vous deviné?
I suppose it's just my lucky day.
Probablement. Tire!
*BOOM*
You're still thinking about the civilians, aren't you?
Sucked in by everlasting night. So I do not think much of them, en vérité.

Fields.MenuText: And yet here you are, thinking.
Don't let Command hear you say that.
That's hardly something they'd like to know back home.

Fields.DialogueText: Thinking about human weakness is not the same as thinking about humans.
What are they going to do? Scuttle me? They'd have to ask Stalin to give me back.
They need heroes back home, not friends.
Hmm. Some of the bodies were recovered after the battle. They were carrying... well, strange things.
Étaient-ils maintenant? Tire!
*BOOM*
Driftwood, compasses... even a ship in a bottle. Almost like...
Offerings. Tire!
*BOOM*
What, like some kind of ritual?
We discussed that penchant you humans have for storytelling. Some of you tell dangerous stories.
But for someone to do this... they'd have to be...
Mad. Stupide. Insensé.
There's more to it than that.
Weak, then. Cela ne fait rien.
Verdun, you're being...
*BOOM*
Action stations for Morgana attack, Capitaine.
Indeed.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, against my initial judgment I have given your civilians some thought.
Have you now?
It began, comme ces choses font souvent, in our library. Have you read about the Taiping Rebellion?
A while ago. Some madman in China said he was Christ's younger brother or something?
Ou quelque chose. It got me reading about other such disasters. You humans and your end-of-the-world stories... they have a distressing way of gaining traction.
I see. You think there's some kind of Morgana cult?
It is not an unreasonable assumption. I have been brushing up on my Russian.  One of the men brought me some recent newspapers. The beach massacre was not the first of its kind.

Fields.MenuText: So there is a pattern of people going to the beach as... sacrifices, you think?
Those poor, lost people. Can you imagine what was going through their minds?
I was under the impression you didn't care about civilians.

Fields.DialogueText: Funeral dress? Naval items? No wonder the civilian casualties are so high, there are willing targets all over Crimea.
Shrapnel, if the reports are any indication.
It is not the bloodshed that concerns me. It is what the bloodshed represents.
Under any other circumstance I would let nature take its course with the cultists.  But the civilians are part of our war machine, and we cannot have some madmen proselytizing among them.
Think shellshock, Verdun. Despair and hope are powerful things.
Perhaps this is what Stalin sought such a large force for. A demonstration, to curb his citizens' suicidal impulses.
The Morgana in our sights ought to suffice.
Pour l'instant, Capitaine. She stirs all the savage instincts into life. If they inspire anything, they should inspire that.
@BATTLE
The Red Baron!
What?
The Red Baron, Capitaine!
Yes, Verdun, there was a man called that. What are you getting at?
Je m'excuse, Capitaine... I was reading about Great War propaganda and it came to me.
What came to you?
The raison d'etre of the Morgana cults. I believe there may be a solution after all.

Fields.MenuText: Start a Belle cult?
What did you have in mind?
I don't know that we can solve them all.

Fields.DialogueText: Laugh if you want, but you are closer than you might think.
Call it a history lesson.
Not with that attitude.
I have given your men plenty of grief about their ghost stories, Capitaine. They only hurt morale. The cults are proof of that. But perhaps they simply need some good stories.
What does the Red Baron have to do with this?
Tout! By the end of the Great War, there were rumors that whole squadrons were hunting him! Who knows how much longer the Germans would have fought on had he lived!
That's a strange thing for a poilu to speculate on.
War is strange, Capitaine. We must know our enemies better than they know themselves.
But the Morganas aren't the sort of enemy that has heroes.
Not yet. We will publicize the faces of those witches, and then we will bayonet them. Let's see people despair then.
What do you need me to do?
The same as always. Get me on the front lines, where I can get a good look at our enemy. This one off our starboard, par exemple...
@BATTLE
I didn't know you could draw.
Some idle sketches, rien de plus. But do not look at the sketches. Look at what they represent.

Fields.MenuText: Drawing Morganas? Did you get inspired by their fashion sense?
Evil?
Is this some kind of proof of concept?

Fields.DialogueText: Jamais en un million d'années. But there is a point to this exercise.
Franchement, you can be so dull sometimes.
Let us say that I wish to tell a story of my own.
I've been at these Morgana sketches all day, and I've drawn up a list of fabric I'll need. If we can copy their style and incorporate it into training, imagine the boost in morale!
Target dummies, eh? I suppose you can't be afraid of something you're exposed to day in and day out.
Ce n'est pas tout à fait vrai. Take it from me - we are always afraid. Our fear can either be a weakness... or a weapon.
Maybe you should run your drills in this costume.
Comment lubrique! Have you seen the indecency of these Morganas? It is like they wear their nightclothes everywhere... it is not fit for a lady or a soldier!
Even so. It might give the crew something else to resent.
The crew listens to me.
When they're running a half marathon on pain of your punishments, maybe. But you're a soldier. You know how people talk.
Hmm... perhaps you have a point.
I trust you to figure it out.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm—let's get to action stations.
Peace on earth and silence in the sky... it was starting to grate on me, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Verdun, you might be interested in this. Have you read today's paper?
Laissez-moi voir... Capitaine! What is the meaning of this!?
"Twelve Women Questioned in ‘Morgana Fashion Show' Scandal?" Seems clear-cut to me.
Incroyable. How on earth was this allowed to happen?
Isn't this what you wanted? It looks like people are adapting to the Morganas already.
Oui, oui, oui, oui, oui. What I want to know is who leaked my sketches! Look there. I spent hours on that bustle!

Fields.MenuText: Nobody owns stories, Verdun. One way or another, other people are going to tell their own.
I can ask around and see who did what on shore leave, but this mystery might never be solved.
I can tell. It's the only thing the newspaper hasn't censored.

Fields.DialogueText: But... but there was military value to my work! This is just... frivolité!
See that you do, Capitaine, before I wrestle the answer out of your men!
Hmph. Philistines.
Look at it this way. The less seriously people take the Morganas, the less people will be afraid of them.
Would you advertise Wehrmacht fashion in Warsaw?
Probably not, but the Morganas aren't really in a position to object. And they're a common enemy. Why not take some good from them as we beat them back?
Perhaps, but I will do these things my way.
You know, I've been thinking. What if you...
Ça suffit! I have a rendezvous with death!
@BATTLE
I thought I'd find you here again.
I am nothing if not reliable. Tire!
*BOOM*
I never did tell you what I had in mind for anti-Morgana propaganda.
Allez. I am a captive audience.
Well, you read the papers. There's only so much people can do with Morgana imagery.
Especially when they are amateur seamstresses.
... Right. And we talked before about making a mark on the world.
Oui. Tire!
*BOOM*

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should be the hero the people are looking for.
Maybe it's not enough to tear down the Morganas.
Have you considered dressing up before an audience?

Fields.DialogueText: Pah. "Every poor fellow in the trenches has to do his duty." Remember the Red Baron? He may have fought for the wrong side, but he was right about some things.
Bien sûr. One of these days we must get around to sinking a few.
Non.
Just hear me out. Maybe what the public is missing is your friendly side.
I would sooner expose myself to friendly fire. I am a soldier, Capitaine. Let me soldier.
I haven't gone to Command about this because I wanted your perspective. You Belles are already being talked about everywhere.
Nobody knows what you are or where you're from. Why not tell them?
Tire!
*BOOM*
... Capitaine. Not even we can answer some of your questions. Do you honestly believe it matters what we are? Shouldn't we be concerned with what we do?
It matters what people think the Morganas are. We've seen enough proof of that.
People already know that you're fighting for them. It might do a world of good if they saw you as a friend.
Tire!
*BOOM*
This is war. We need allies, not friends. The greatest glory will be theirs who fought.
@BATTLE
Who is that skulking around the mess hall, Capitaine?
Who are you talking about?
The scrawny thing who keeps writing.
Oh, him. The Soviet Navy contacted me the other day about sending us a war correspondent. I'd been meaning to tell you.
Oh, formidable! Another propagandist.
Weren't we talking about using the Morganas' image against them?
For the benefit of those who fought them, Capitaine. No doubt our journalist friend has been advised to speak of us in a way that paints his leaders in the best possible light.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to like him. Just let him talk to you for a moment. The crew is doing it.
It's only for the rest of our tour in the Black Sea. You can avoid him most of the time if it means that much to you.
What does that matter if people are inspired?

Fields.DialogueText: Mon Dieu, I hope they tell him everything. He'll have something to think about, and I'll be able to step up my training.
Another coast, another country, another correspondent. This will not end, Capitaine.
My cause is war, Capitaine. Not Communism, not politics, not whatever you humans fight these battles over. You start things, I end them.
It's out of my hands at this point. Don't hurt him?
La guerre est la guerre. He should be prepared to meet the shell's embrace of fire.
As long as it's the Morganas' and not yours.
Here comes one now. I do not believe in promises.
@BATTLE
That war correspondent has been quiet lately.
Bon. He should keep at it.
This doesn't have anything to do with you, does it?
Of course it has something to do with me. The little belette would not be here if not to show the Soviets their new pet.

Fields.MenuText: You know you're more than that.
The least you could do is smile. What will he report back about you if he doesn't like you?
I'm doing what I can to keep him out of the way.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr, but does the Soviet Union?
That the witches are being beaten back by an even scarier witch? It is not my job to be liked.
Which I appreciate. But you cannot be everywhere at once. The press, on the other hand...
Have you spoken to him at all?
Une seul fois. It was productive, actually.
Productive how?
I caught him snooping in my quarters. He will not repeat his error.
Snooping? Verdun, this is serious! What else could he have been up to?
Perhaps it is too strong a word. I was touching up a dress last night and made the mistake of answering the door wearing it. He made the greater mistake of having knocked in the first place.
Whatever you do, don't kill him.
He knows my secret. He will be treated as I treat any of the crew.
A half marathon before dawn?
A half marathon before dawn.
I suppose it'll be good copy.
He'll survive, at the very least. This Morgana might not be so lucky.
@BATTLE
Looks like that correspondent's story is in today's paper.
Donnez-lui ici.
Take your time.
How is...
Tsk. He misspelled "tortuous."
In Russian?
Bien sûr.
Heh. I take it that he was glad to leave.
After being shot at, who would not be?

Fields.MenuText: Forcing him to do calisthenics until you were tired probably didn't endear you to him.
So what does he have to say?
Well, are you a war hero?

Fields.DialogueText: I do not tire easily. Neither should anyone working alongside me.
Surprisingly... quite a lot.
That is for your descendants to decide.
Go on.
"Aboard her namesake, she has brought the children of many warring nations to heel, strikes down the Neizvestniy wherever they may appear, and has broken and rebuilt this author..."
That's amazing!
"... in short, Verdun is a true daughter of the Revolution come home to roost." Well, you cannot win them all.
Never mind the sloganeering. This is exactly what people need!
Capitaine, you and I disagree on many things. But I have to admit to... satisfaction.
You think he got you right?
Plus ou moins. Strip away the Party language and I am neither benevolent nor malevolent. I am what I am, and the human race may choose whether to approve.
They do, Verdun. You may not appreciate it, or it might not be important to you, but they do.
The world is full of disillusions as never told in the old days, Capitaine. But if what I do out at sea can shatter them for those on the home front... I suppose that is a victory unto itself.
You're leaving the world in better shape than when you arrived, whether you like it or not.
Merci, Capitaine. With your permission, I shall continue that glorious work with our quarry there.
@BATTLE
C'est vrai, then? Are we to leave the Black Sea?
Stalin himself is traveling to Sevastopol to see you off.
Un honneur douteux, but an honor nonetheless.
I know you'll be on your best behavior.
Make no mistake, Capitaine, I admire the Russian resilience - few countries would burn their cities rather than surrender them to Napoleon. I trust the Soviets will have the same resolve.
Hm. Would you say you also admire Germany or Japan?
I can appreciate the coherence of a formation while disliking those who order the cohering. Oui, in that same way.
Well, I hear we might be seeing action in the North Sea soon. Does that do anything for you?
It rather does, Capitaine. Not a day goes by without a hunt or a skirmish of some kind. Perhaps there I can do some real good.
You know, there haven't been any Morgana cults since your story ran. It might be early to say, but I know you've done plenty of good where you are.
How can you possibly know?
I can't. They call it faith.
Still to the last of crumbling time you are a romantic.
No place on the battlefield for us, I take it?
Au contraire. Soldiers need your kind. You say many things we cannot find the words for. It keeps me sane, at any rate.
Verdun, I don't know what to say. Thank you.
A proper eulogy will be all the thanks I need. Let me ensure you will be around to write it.
